raw_text:
Oscars race enters final furlong
 
 The race for the Oscars entered its final stages as the deadline for voters to choose their winners passed.
 
 The 5,808 Academy voters had until Tuesday afternoon to return their ballots - any late submissions will not be included in the count. The next five days will be spent counting the voting forms and preparing the winners' envelopes. Best actor nominee Leonardo DiCaprio is to present a statuette for the first time at the LA ceremony on Sunday.
 
 The 30-year-old actor, who is nominated for playing Howard Hughes in The Aviator, will join other hopefuls such as co-star Cate Blanchett, Natalie Portman and Kate Winslet as Oscar presenters. The only people who will know the Oscar winners before they are revealed at the ceremony will be the auditors who are in charge of looking after the ballot count.
 
 After collating the results, they are responsible for sealing the results in the famous golden envelopes which will be revealed by a host of celebrity presenters at the ceremony. Former Academy Award winners Gwyneth Paltrow, Dustin Hoffman and Halle Berry will also present prizes. The event at the Kodak Theatre will be attended by 3,300 people, including some of the best-known names in film, and organisers say they expect it will be watched on television by one billion people around the world. One current concern is the torrential rain which has lashed Los Angeles for the past week, flooding suburbs and causing mudslides. It is hoped the forecast for Sunday, for cool weather but no rain, will prove accurate. "The last time it rained on Oscars night was in the mid-to-late 1980s," said Oscars communications director John Pavlik. "We have had rain up until the day before the show many times, but for some reason the Oscar gods always shine on Sunday and we hope they will do so again this year," he added.
llama3.2:1b: The Academy Awards race entered its final stages as voters cast their ballots, with the deadline today.
The winners' envelopes were to be sealed by auditors who would reveal them at a ceremony attended by 3,300 people.
Presenters including Leonardo DiCaprio and Cate Blanchett will highlight nominees such as Howard Hughes and Natalie Portman for the first time.
llama3.2:3b: Academy voters submitted ballots by Tuesday afternoon, marking the end of the voting period.
The next five days will focus on counting votes and preparing winners' envelopes.

Leonardo DiCaprio will present an Oscar for the first time at the LA ceremony on Sunday as part of a lineup that includes Cate Blanchett, Natalie Portman, Kate Winslet, and former winners Gwyneth Paltrow, Dustin Hoffman, and Halle Berry.
The event is expected to be watched by 1 billion people worldwide, but heavy rain in Los Angeles has caused concerns about the ceremony's weather forecast.
gemma2:2b: The Oscars voting deadline has passed, with counting to begin.
Leonardo DiCaprio will present an award at the ceremony.
Winners will be revealed in sealed envelopes, presented by celebrity presenters.
The event will have 3,300 attendees and be watched by a global audience.
Recent rain has caused concerns about weather conditions, but a forecast of cool, dry weather is anticipated.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Oscars are in their final days as voters return their ballots to the Academy.
Best actors Leonardo DiCaprio and Cate Blanchett were announced as Oscar presenters.
The event is expected to attract 3,300 people with some of the best-known names in film attending.
A torrential rain has impacted the city since Monday and the organizers hope it will not affect the ceremony.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Academy Awards race comes down to the wire as voting deadlines pass; Leonardo DiCaprio to present Oscars for first time.
Counting of 5,808 votes underway until Sunday's ceremony, with presentation by winners including Paltrow, Hoffman and Berry expected.
Torrential rain lashing LA has organisers hoping for fair weather on Oscar night.
qwen2.5:3b: The race for Oscars nominees is nearing its conclusion with Academy voters submitting their ballots by Tuesday afternoon.
The 5,808 members must return their voting forms by then; any late submissions won't be included in the count.
Counting and preparation will take place over the next five days, leading up to the ceremony on Sunday at the LA's Kodak Theatre.
Leonardo DiCaprio, nominated for Best Actor for his role in The Aviator, will present a statuette.
Other notable Oscar presenters include Cate Blanchett, Natalie Portman, Kate Winslet, and celebrities like Gwyneth Paltrow, Dustin Hoffman, and Halle Berry.
Over 3,300 attendees are expected to be at the event, which is anticipated to be watched by one billion people worldwide.
Organizers are worried about potential rainfall, with rain having caused flooding in Los Angeles suburbs; however, a forecast predicts cool weather without rain for Sunday's ceremony.

tinyllama:1.1b: Leonardo DiCaprio is set to present a statuette at the Academy Awards ceremony, making his debut as an Oscar presenter.

The 30-year-old actor received a nomination for playing Howard Hughes in "The Wolf of Wall Street" and will join other hopefuls such as Catel Blanche, Natalie Portman, and Kate Winslet to deliver a speech before the audience selects the winner on Sunday.
Former Academy Award winners Duettin Hoffman and Gwynetth Paltrow will also present prizes at the ceremony in Los Angeles, with an estimated attendance of 3,300 people attending the event.

The torrential rainfall this weekend, coupled with a potential for more rain on Sunday evening, is expected to affect the show's proceedings, but organizers have expressed confidence that everything will go according to plan.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Academy Awards (Oscars) are set to take place in Los Angeles, California, this coming Sunday.
It is a highly anticipated event where renowned actors and filmmakers compete for prestigious awards such as Best Actor and Best Picture.
However, this year's race is extra challenging due to rainy weather that has affected several key stages of the voting process.
As of now, it is uncertain if nominations will be revealed beforehand or whether final countdowns will take place during the event.
Many have expressed concern over the impact of heavy rain on the event itself and its attendees, which could jeopardize the integrity of the awards.
Despite these concerns, Oscars organizers are adamant that Sunday's ceremony will go smoothly and remain a memorable experience for millions of people around the world.
